think Spencer himself kind of puts onto
the project
just take the titling of the first EP
for example the Dream Land EP marimba
and and drums or take the titling
of the debut album Oregon music not

both of the two releases that moodface
started out with kind of imply that yeah
this is my music but it's not really the

doesn't really seem to be the case with

Spencer is not just going solo this time

actually a finished band by the name of
sin I hope I'm pronouncing that

make this time around and I'll be honest
I did not enjoy those two previous
moon-faced releases definitely not as
much as I'm enjoying this and I think
even Spencer himself would not blame me
for it for me being a guy that's enjoyed
Spencer Krug songwriting for a handful
of years now it's great to hear him
in front of the full band again
especially since a lot of stuff for
Spencer kind of seems to be in limbo
right now this project has not exactly
started off very well and the two indie
darling bands that brought him to where
he is today are in the midst of an
indefinite hiatus right now
and there's really no sign of them being
sunset rubdown and Wolf Parade coming
back anytime soon and if you read into
the very personal lyrics that Spencer
has written for this album and and
really just taken them for face value
I'd say Spencer just went through a
pretty ugly breakup which is sad but in
a way I kind of feel like this is
revitalized what Spencer is doing with
his music because he really is one of
those singer songwriters that has a very
unique voice lots of character lots of a
broto and his songs and his very
emotional vocal delivery kind of thrives
off of off of sadness and will also draw
his songs out musically in really
interesting ways the kind of sidestep
your average verse chorus verse
structure usually a Spencer Curt track
requires a few extra lessons to really
get into the meat of it and I guess on
some level understand it but he's still
not beyond writing a track that kind of
hooks me up first listen a track that
comes to mind is the song paper lease
which was on that Swan Lake album enemy
mine and appeared on that last sunset
rubbed down LP - and now as far as the
sound goes on this thing it does not at
first on the surface appear to be all
that much different than your average
album that that Spencer is involved with
Spencer's voice sounds just as emotional
as ever sort of bordering on being kind
of over the top there's just a perfect
splash of reverb on there there's lots
of Airy synthesizers shimmering and
guitars drums that have quite a bit of
ambience on them not a lot of punch more
atmosphere and Sanai from what I
understand is is more of an
mental group with huge influences coming
from the world of krautrock and that
does show up on a few tracks here tracks
like teary eyes and bloody lips and
shitty city both have very driving
rhythms strong synthesizers very
electronic textures to the effects
surrounding those songs but most of
what's on this LP kind of feels like the
band conforming to Spencer's songwriting
which cukoo cukoo could be a good thing
for the fans I guess if there is a
notable change because of the subject
matter of this album the drama seems to
be turned up a little bit more than
usual in a good way it's like Spencer
really wanted the emotions on this album
to feel really grandiose with these
great large movements and and fireworks
style explosions of sound like the
opener which is also the title track it
starts off with these sparse piano
chords very repetitive floor tom drum
beat some bouncy reverb but it
eventually just blows up into these
glistening keyboards and of course
Spencer's singing throughout the track
and his lyrics are a focal point as
usual he's kind of telling the story of
how to me from from what I interpret he
is not the bloodthirsty carnivore that

stay interested and over the hook

piano chords
there's just something so perfectly

just it kind of reminded me of a wedding

thought but that's kind of the
juxtaposition that you're getting with
with a lot of tracks on this album you
